introduction.paragraph: This request retrieves a sorted list of changes made to documents in the database, in time order of application. Each document appears at most once, ordered by its most recent change, regardless of how many times it's been changed.

This request can be used to listen for update and modifications to the database for post processing or synchronization. A continuously connected changes feed is a reasonable approach for generating a real-time log for most applications.

body.paragraph: This request does not have any required headers.

row.entry: A comma-separated list of channel names. The response will be filtered to only documents in these channels. (This parameter must be used with the filter parameter; see below.)
Includes conflict information in the response. Ignored if include_docs isn’t true.
Specifies type of change feed. Valid values: normal, continuous, longpoll, websocket
Indicates that the documents should be filtered by channel; the channels parameter lists the channels to include. The only valid value is sync_gateway/bychannel.

Interval in milliseconds at which an empty line (CRLF) is written to the response. This helps prevent gateways from deciding the socket is idle and closing it. Only applicable to longpoll or continuous feeds. Overrides any timeout to keep the feed alive indefinitely. Setting to 0 results in no heartbeat.
Indicates whether to include the associated document with each result. If there are conflicts, only the winning revision is returned.
Limits the number of result rows to the specified value. Using a value of 0 has the same effect as the value 1.
Starts the results from the change immediately after the given sequence ID. Sequence IDs should be considered opaque; they come from the last_seq property of a prior response.
Number of revisions to return in the changes array. main_only returns the current winning revision, all_docs returns all leaf revisions including conflicts and deleted former conflicts.
Maximum period in milliseconds to wait for a change before the response is sent, even if there are no results. Only applicable for longpoll or continuous feeds. Setting to 0 results in no timeout.

body.paragraph: This response uses only standard HTTP headers.
The response message body contains a JSON document with the following objects;

row.entry: List of the document’s leafs. Each leaf object contains one field, rev.
